What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I came away from the course with a strong conceptual understanding of the theories and frameworks behind international order and with the ability to assess the current and future threats to it. I also honed my ability to engage with academic articles and present the main ideas to peers.
I gained a lot of background on the important terms and literature of international relations study. I also learned more about the institutions that make up our international system.
Good overview of the way IR treats questions of international order and cooperation

This course is a great introduction to the concept of "international order." At the beginning of the semester, we read and discussed various important works by many of the key thinkers in this discourse. These authors included Ikenberry, Mearsheimer, Trachtenberg, Hurd, Keohane, Huntington, Fukuyama, and more. Having established a strong foundation of what international order means, how it is treated, and how it came to be, the course moved onto to more contemporary discussions of international order and critiques of it. We discussed the role of small states in constituting order, considered the roles of non-state acts and illiberal regimes, as well as cyber warfare and its potential for instability. I now feel very comfortable reading other papers in IR as I recognize most of the names and concepts authors reference and take for granted, and this course has prepared me for strong future research in this subject.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Fascinating subject matter, strong ability to relate course material to current events, clear connections between topics on the syllabus.  

Weaknesses: It felt a bit redundant to structure the student presentations around summarizing the readings, as the quizzes ensured that we had all done the readings! Other than that, really no improvements could be made.
I think the readings are great and our class conversations were interesting, but that the seminar itself focused a little too much on summarizing the readings we all did.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you are interested in understanding why our international structure, which we often take as a given, looks the way it does, and if you are interested in developing the knowledge and skills necessary to evaluate threats to the current order, this is a class for you. There is a lot of reading assigned each week that you truly do have to do in order to engage well in class, so just a fair warning.
Yes great course and great Professor
Yes, if a student wants to gain a solid background in the study of IR.
Yes! This is an excellent course, and Professor Pratt is a very kind and engaging professor. This course is a great way to build on more so introductory IR courses, and I highly recommend!
